projectDesc.p: "The brilliant Dante’s joke" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Dantes, Poeta noster, cum exul Senis esset, et aliquando in ecclesia Minorum, cubito super altare posito, cogitabundus aliquid secretius scrutaretur animo,
app.rdg: When our poet Dante was in exile in Siena, he was once in a mendicant church where he was searching his soul and privately pondering something.

app.lem: accessit ad eum quidam, nescio quid molestius petens.
app.rdg: A man then walked up to him and asked something very annoying.

app.lem: Tum Dantes: 'Dic mihi,' inquit, 'quae est maxima omnium belluarum?'
app.rdg: To which Dante replied: “Tell me, which is the biggest of all animals?”

app.lem: 'O elephas! sine me,' inquit, 'maiora verbis tuis cogitantem, noli esse molestus.'
app.rdg: “Oh elephant, leave me alone to ponder things greater than your words and stop being annoying!"
